characters: THE REAL YOU, I SAW IT, YOU SELFISH
ASSHOLE. I SHOULD KILL YOU, YOU
GET OUT OF THE WAY, MORON
I WISH I'D NEVER MET YOU
CREDIT CARD TO PROVE A POINT TO
I'M HERE BECAUSE I NEED SOME GODDAM
HOPE YOU GET CANCER AND ROT IN
BOX OF CONDOMS I BOUGHT YOU
TRYING TO GET PAST THE TRAFFIC
KNOW WHO WOULD CUT UP HER GOD DAMN

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: It’s not that I don’t love you. Elle puts a teapot into a cupboard. Inside is a cap from academic’s cap and gown.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What the hell’s this doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: These last four months have been the... Olivia is trying not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The last four months have been some of the best months of my life.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well. It’s been a short life. Comparatively.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I’ve learned - I’ve learned so much from you -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m very wise. Olivia knuckles her eye.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very wizened.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You’re not wizened. Elle puts the medieval looking cap into a closet next to professor's striped red academic gown.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hah. So what have you learned, exactly? Aside from backgammon? (xe gown) There’s a rip in this Goddam thing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I've learned...not to buy into the system. I’ve learned persistence. Courage. Dedication to one’s craft. In the face of...

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: All reason?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You're still a wonderful poet.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (with self-contempt) I’m not a poet, I’m an academic. An unemployed one -

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You should send the new poems to your editor -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She has dementia. So she might actually like ‘em. Look, are you breaking up with me or giving me a pep talk here? Stick with the narrative.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Please. Elle -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: We always knew...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: We always knew what?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I mean, you’re your age, and I’m... rapidly approaching fifty. Olivia smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was gonna happen here? You don’t need a crystal ball or anything.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Do you love me? (pause) Are you in love with me?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Christ. Here. Blow your nose. She hands Olivia a tissue. Olivia blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You've never said it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: “It is a tale full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.”

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: What is, love?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: --.-I’m gonna vacuum.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Doesn't love conquer everything?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: No. Elle involuntarily glances up at a photo on the wall. The photo is of a striking-looking woman (named Violet), taken in the late eighties. The woman looks into the camera, out at Elle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. It does not conquer everything. (pause) Four months. We were together for four months. Try thirty-eight years. Try being with someone for thirty-eight years. (pause) You're a footnote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “A footnote?” That’s...that’s a horrible thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well. I’m a horrible person. (pause) I’m gonna take a shower before I vacuum. You can let yourself out.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Okay. I guess that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yup. That’s it. They stand there a moment. Then Olivia comes over and kisses Elle.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Elle is statue-like. Doesn’t reciprocate.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Leave the key on the coffee table. Elle goes off. Olivia stands there a moment, numb. Then she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water goes on. Water hits Elle’s face. From behind Elle’s head, we see the Elle’s back - a COLORFUL DRAGONFLY. to SHAKE as she starts to cry. Her fists clench. She pounds the wall of the shower. top of a large TATTOO on Elle’s shoulders begin CUT TO: Elle is at the sink, brushing her teeth vigorousl She bares her teeth at the mirror.  INT. ELLE’S APARTMENT - DAY 3 Elle is sitting on the floor, wearing her striped academi gown and cap. There are photos spread out on the floor in front of her. photo of her standing at the podium at a graduation cerem in her gown. Photos of her with the woman on the wall, at poetry event in a cafe, at various stages in life. With a little girl - her daughter. The DOORBELL rings. She looks up quickly. Her breath catches. INT. ELLE’S APARTMENT - DAY 4 Elle opens the door. Standing there is a young woman. Age 18. This is her granddaughter, SAGE. She is pretty. Her nails are raggedly bitten.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Sage. Sage stands in the hallway, shifting on her toes. Nervous

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Hi Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hi. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Sage comes in. Elle glances out into the hall before she closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Thought I’d drop by.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Did you call?  Sage INT. Elle Elle Sage Elle

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No. I just wanted to see you. Why are you dressed like that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Oh I’m just sitting here being maudlin. You want some tea? nods.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: makes them tea.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I need some help, Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Okay. looks at Sage, who doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on? doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not a mind-reader.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I need six-hundred dollars. Six- hundred and thirty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant. takes a couple of cups from the cupboard behind Sage.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to have a baby. (stares into her tea) I want to get an abortion. And I’m broke. I have eighteen dollars. (pause) You think that’s terrible?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Which part of it?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: All of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It’s nothing to dance a jig about. Have you told your mother?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Mom? She’d have a stroke. She'd start strangling me, and then she’d have a stroke. She demonstrates this. She drops her pantomime.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well, she’d strangle you alright. The kettle WHISTLES. EXT. ELLE’S TERRACE — DAY 5A Sage and Elle have tea.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I’m such an idiot. Such an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: So was I, when I was your age.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do? What am I gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You already said what you’re gonna do. Right? I mean you’ve put some thought into this. (pause) Have you? Sage nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cause this is something you will probably think about at some moment each day for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm... (pause) Do you have it? Do you have money?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Honey, at the moment, I have forty- three dollars.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Forty-three dollars! You're joking!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I’m not. That’s what I have until I get a check end of next week.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: How do you have so little money?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I got sick of being in debt, so I just paid it all off. Every cent I still owed. Wanted to get that weight off my back. I mean I still had hospital bills from Vi. Twenty- seven thousand dollars worth.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you ask mom to help?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you? Sage doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t need help. I’m sweeping the decks clean here. Next week I’m supposed to get a check for some guest lectures I gave at Santa Cruz. I had it all planned out.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Well do you have a credit card?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I cut my credit cards into little pieces. (points) Look, I made a wind chime out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I was transmogrifying my life into art.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What kind of adult doesn’t have a credit card!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Credit cards infantilize you. They turn you into a pod person. Come on, you must have a credit card -

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Mom confiscated it after I crashed the car in the garage. Shit! Shit!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Alright. Alright. Calm down. We’re gonna deal with this.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: We are?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes. We are. Where’d you get this 630 dollar number?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I went by a clinic. Called Pine Rapids.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I have an appointment for the procedure.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: For when?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Five-forty-five.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Five-forty-five? You mean today? (Sage nods) It’s 9 o’clock already!  10

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: They don’t have another appointment open this week! And I can’t wait. I feel sick. And every day, every day that goes by...

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Okay well, I know a women’s health clinic where you can get one for free.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Vi used to volunteer there. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle brushes some leaves off the tarp covering a car. She pulls the tarp off, revealing a 1955 Dodge Royal Lancer.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You still have Vi’s car?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Course I still have Vi’s car. Give me a hand, would you? Sage helps her. Elle puts the tarp in the trunk. Elle starts the car. Only it doesn’t start.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: A young man is giving Elle a jump start with some cables his truck.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t wake you up, did I?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (she did) No. The young man glances at Sage.  11

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She’s already pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying. Don’t get any ideas. The engine turns over. Loud RAP MUSIC blasts for a moment Elle turns it down.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks! The car pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive into a mini mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle stops the car in the mini mall. She squints out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Where the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. When’s the last time you were here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I dunno. 10 years ago? It must have moved. (points) I think that was it. It was right in there. Where that coffee place is. Christ. It musta closed down. (pause) I could use some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are drinking coffee in a cafe. Elle is at the condiments station putting sugar in her coffee. Sage sits a table.  12

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (reading) Women’s Health Action Center. It closed five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: How could they close this place down? Why didn’t they let us know? We could have had a rally! Course...five years ago, we weren't going to any rallies. (drinks coffee) This is bilgewater. So where do you get a reasonably priced abortion? All you can get nowadays is this shitty coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Grandma, uh — Sage is looking nervously at a conservative looking coupl the next table. Elle puts more sugar into her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: How far along are you again? When was your last period?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Ten weeks ago. The manager of the coffee bar is looking at Elle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: My last period was twenty five years ago. We did a ceremony for it, Vi and I. (pause) 600 dollars for an abortion! What the hell! That’s highway robbery! The manager comes over.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but I’m going to have to ask you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I’m going have to ask you to leave.  13

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You're “going to have to?” When are you “going to have to” ask us to leave?

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to ask you to leave now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: So you mean you are asking us to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yes, you're disturbing the customers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What customers? I’m a customer. Do you know what a customer is?

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: I know what a customer is.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: A customer is someone who pays for your services. So I’m a customer. What other customer are we disturbing? Them? Ozzie and Harriet over here?

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: We're disturbing you. Isn’t that right?

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s right. You are also disturbing me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Because I'm talking about abortions?

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s right. Now please take your coffee and enjoy it somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: This used to be an abortion clinic, do you know that? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where you are standing right now, there were countless unintended pregnancies terminated. The nearby woman GASPS.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Please leave. Leave now.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Wait, I’m going to enjoy this three dollar “drip” coffee first! I’ve got news for you - all coffee drips! So you don’t have to call it “drip” coffee - that’s a redundancy! Hey, look, it’s dripping! Elle POURS THE REST OF HER COFFEE ON THE FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I enjoyed that! That was some good drip coffee!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (to manager) I’m sorry!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Why should you be sorry? He should be sorry! They go to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: French press.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: French press coffee. It doesn’t drip.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well, I guess not. Touche. Can you believe that guy? These bastards think they can turn the clock back fifty years. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Crap. She stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I really have to use the rest room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager looks up from where he is mopping up coffee.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Here, lemme help you with that.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE MANAGER
dialogues.text: No, that’s alright -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I insist, I feel terrible. Elle grabs some napkins and gets down to help him mop the spill.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, do you need a key to use the bathroom or is it unlocked? He stares at her. 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle joins Sage outside the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Okay, everyone’s friends now. So who’s the guy?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: The guy! I assume there was a penis involved. Who is he? One night stand?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No. He’s kind of my boyfriend. I don’t know.  Sage nods. 16

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You don’t know? Well who does know? If you don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: He was supposed to get the money by this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: He didn’t get it. He told me he would. But he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Alright, well. This is his problem too. (stops) You understand that, right?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you? Understand that?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Of course, he’s not the one who’s pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well that’s the fucking problem right? He’s not the one who’s pregnant. He’d be shitting his pants if he were. He’d find the fucking money if he was about to swell up like he swallowed a watermelon.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Let's go talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Who, Cam? I don’t know if that’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: “Cam?” His name is “Cam?”  17 INT. CAM’S HOUSE - DAY 13 A small house. CAM opens the door. He looks annoyed. Cam is eighteen. Working on a scruff-beard. He has a hock jersey on with a marijuana leaf on it.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Are your parents here?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: So can we come in?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Whatever, yeah. They come in. The house is messy. Cramped.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Umm, you were supposed to get the money.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I couldn't get it. That fuckin asshole wouldn’t front me the money. I thought he would.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well you’re gonna have to get it, Cam. Half. Give us half the money.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: My grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Grandma? Yo Grandma, what you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Listen, you have to take responsibility for this.  18

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: How do I know it was me?

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: He picks up a hockey stick, starts messing with a piece o balled up tape.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You heard me.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I didn’t sleep with anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: You slept with Mike.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Last year. He used a condom.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you use a condom? What'd it, slip off?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What? What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: She didn’t say anything -

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Look, she said it wasn’t her time.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Her time? What are you, a moron? Are you both morons? Don’t they teach kids sex-ed anymore? Cam puts down the hockey stick. Points at Elle.

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Listen Grandma, you better watch yourself.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Look at this loser. You know, some people shouldn’t grow beards because it makes their face look like an armpit.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (laughs involuntarily) Grandma!  19

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I’m serious, old lady, don’t fuck with me!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Then give us the money!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I don’t have the money, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Grandma -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: “Bitch?” Look, you have the money, you little prick -

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: What the fuck? Are you bitches crazy?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Get the God damn money!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: Get out of my home! I mean it, you old bitch! Get out! Or I’1l1 fuck you up!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You’1l fuck me up?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I will, I’11 fuck you up. Instead of going to the door, Elle grabs the hockey stick HITS Cam with it. HARD in the HEAD. He goes down, CRUMPLING to the ground. SAGE SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (groans) Uuh - Elle HITS him again, in the RIBS this time.

dialogues.speaker: CAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God, oh God - you hit me -  14 20

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I‘ll hit you again, “bitch!”

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: How much money do you have?

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: I don’t have - She HITS HIM in the LEG.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Where?!

dialogues.speaker: CAM
dialogues.text: In my sock drawer! INT. ELLE’S CAR - DAY 14 Elle is sitting in her car, smoothing out and counting crumpled bills. It’s mostly ones. Sage is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I like your boyfriend. He’s special. Really charismatic. I can see how you’d be attracted to him. Sage doesn’t say anything. Elle opens a little baggie with some buds of weed in it a small pack of rolling papers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was in his sock drawer too. Smells pretty good. Red hairs. Sage gets out of the car. Starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Where are you going? Hey!  21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle catches up with Sage.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Where the hell are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! Mom’s right! You're crazy!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Why, cause I rapped that little shit across the knuckles?!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Everyone’s gonna talk about it!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: He’s not gonna tell people. What’s he gonna say? “Sage’s grandmother beat me up?”

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You could have killed him!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Nah, I hit him in the hard part of his head. Stop! Stop... Sage walks a few steps more, then leans over and gags, throwing up a little.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No! I’m not okay! I’m pregnant! I'm fucking pregnant! Elle puts her hand on Sage’s back. Sage stands up, wiping her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have an anger problem!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: No, I have an asshole problem. When people are assholes, it makes me angry. Especially if they’re being assholes to my granddaughter. They stand there a moment.  16 17 Sage EXT. They INT. Elle 22

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. We gotta get going here. We have to get like 550 dollars still. (pause) Come on. There’s someone who owes me four hundred bucks. Maybe she has it. Let’s go. (pause) Or you could just call your mom and ask her for the money. thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: drive.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: is pensive.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: So your mom says I’m crazy?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You know that. You know mom thinks you're crazy. She thinks I’m crazy too.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You’re not crazy enough.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Just an impression. (pause) You need to be able to say “screw you” sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I say “screw you.”

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You didn’t say screw you to that little creep back there.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: -.--No, I guess not. I guess I didn’t. (pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom says you have problems dealing with people. Since Aunt Violet died. She says you’re philanthropic.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: “Philanthropic?” What?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No, wait - misanthropic.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Misanthropic. (pause) Well. (pause) That’s an understatement. Elle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle and Sage walk into a tattoo parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the front of the store a man is getting an elaborate tattoo. The tattoo artist is a young woman with a lot of piercings.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (to tattoo artist) Is Deathy here? The tattoo artist calls out over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hold on! DEATHY comes out of the back. Deathy is a much-tattoed po operative trans-gender woman.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit! Elle! It’s Elle!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hiya Deathy! Deathy hugs Elle.  24

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: My granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: No! I haven't seen you since you were a baby!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: I changed your diapers! Now I feel old.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hey, could I have that four-hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Oh God, Elle. Really?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I need it. She’s pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Oh. She needs a “Bortion,” hunh?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. She needs a “Bortion.”

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Jesus. Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: We used to have this schtick where this girl needed a “Bortion.” Like she didn’t know it was called “an abortion.” She thinks it’s called “a Bortion.”

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: A “schtick?” That’s horrible.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It is, kind of. So do you have that money, honey? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Christ, I wish I did. Your Grandma really helped me out, a while ago. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had these defective boobs that were leaking, just leaking silicone down into my knees. It was awful. Elle here came through for me. And now you need me and I’m broke. I’m fucking broke. (pause) I can give you a tattoo. That I can do. You want a tattoo, darling?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What? No. Thank you. We have to get going.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: How long would it take? For like a little one?

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Oh honey, not long. Fifteen minutes? I’m a quick draw.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe it’d help me collect my thoughts. We gotta strategize here.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The needle is BUZZING. Elle is getting a tattoo, a simple O tattooed on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Don’t you have any rich friends? What about Deanne and Margot?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I kind of gave them hell last time I saw them. Cause they just disappeared when Vi got ill. Along with everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: What about all your academic pals?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: They're all broke and stingy. And they’re all in Santa Cruz. We need the money now.  26

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What’s O for?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s not an O. It’s a circle. It was the quickest one.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Looks like an 0.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: I thought it was for orgasm.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, it’s for that.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: It’s not for “Olivia?” Elle's face tightens.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Isn't Olivia the name of your girlfriend? Can’t you ask her for money?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t have a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Mom said you did. She said you had a girlfriend called Olivia.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I knew I shouldn’t tell your mother anything.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Because she’s so judgemental. “Judge Judy.”

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. “Judge Judy.” (pause) You have a violet tattoo, right? For Aunt Violet?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. That I do.  27

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: You ever see her dragonfly? I did that!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s badass. Deathy works.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you miss her? Violet?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I miss her all the time.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: That was a great love story, you and Vi. Course she put up with a lot.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Nothing, darling, just you’re not the easiest toke. But that’s why I love you. So what is the O for?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: O’s a big letter for women. You got “Ovaries.” Origami. Openness. Orifice.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Cheeri-os.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Oven. Old. Odd. Ossuary. Out.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Olivia.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Whatever. Yeah. As it happens. Elle purses her lips.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Done!

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: By the register. Elle is patting her tattoo with some cot with bacitracin on it.  20 28

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: How much do you think first editions are worth?

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: First editions of what? Of your stuff?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: My stuff? Those aren’t worth anything.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: But you’re famous.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: No, I was marginally well-known. Forty years ago. But I have some valuable first editions. Betty Friedan. I got a couple of signed Simone de Beauvoir books. Carla wanted them.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: Who's Carla?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You know, she owns the Bonobo cafe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gonna sell my God damned first editions. They’re probably worth a few thousand, but I'll give her a break. What the hell am I hanging onto them for anyway? See Sage, I told you this’d clear my head.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHY
dialogues.text: (to Sage) Hey, darling, here’s thirty-five bucks. It all adds up. (looks over) And here’s another thirty I’m just gonna borrow from the register. INT. ELLE’S APARTMENT - DAY 20 Back to Elle’s apartment. Elle and Sage enter. Elle goes to her answering machine. There are two messages. Elle presses the answering machine button.  29

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
dialogues.text: You have two messages. First message, sent today at 11:03. The first message is a hang-up. ANSWERING MACHINE (CONT’D) Second message, sent today at 11:04. The second message is a hang-up too. Elle bites her cheek. Stares at the answering machine. She looks over. Sage is leaning over the sink, retching a bit, spitting saliva.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You alright? Sage looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want some ginger ale?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I hate ginger ale.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What? You love ginger ale. We used to have these little tea parties, only you didn’t like tea, so we’d put ginger ale in the teapot.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (pause) Okay. It’s almost 12:30.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It will. We’re gonna sell some damn first editions. Here. Check em out. Elle has a shelf of old first editions, along with a numb of copies of books of poetry that she wrote.  30

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That fuckin’ Carla is gonna go apeshit for them. She was over here for dinner once, she wanted to buy them from me, right then. Elle pulls a few books out. Sage picks up The Feminine Mystique.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: The Feminine Mystique? What’s The Feminine Mystique?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Mystique’s a character in X-Men.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What? What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Want me to google how much it’s worth?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Go ahead. Signed first edition.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I‘1l look it up on Ebay.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Ebay, Google, whatever. The Feminine Mystique by Betty Friedan. You know The Wizard of Oz, when the curtain gets pulled aside, and they see the Wizard’s a fake? Cause that dog, Toto pulls the curtain? She was like Toto. (pause) Maybe not a great metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Five thousand three hundred ninety dollars?  31

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No, Fifty-three dollars and ninety cents. There’s one on sale here on Ebay for 53.90.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Fifty-three dollars?! That's bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: First edition, good condition, fifty-three dollars ninety cents. She shows Elle her phone. Elle squints at it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: How can you read that?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: There’s a stain on it. Is this wine?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, wine. Probably. Shit. Well I’m just gonna bring all these things. Look at this. The Prime of Life by Simone de Beauvoir. This is her autobiography. Dare I ask if you know who Simone de Beauvoir is?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No idea. Guess I’m an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Guess you are. Sage looks like she’s been slapped.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (mutters ) Screw you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What? Couldn’t hear you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Not bad.  32

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You don’t even know who Mystique is. Elle laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle and Sage get out of Elle’s car, both carrying a few books. They walk towards a cafe with a Bonobo Ape painted on the window.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: So what’s a bonobo?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: A very advanced ape. The females run the show, they masturbate all the time, and they don’t have wars, unlike chimps and humans.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: So you think women are better than men?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Men are okay. My father was a man.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Mine wasn’t. He was a sperm.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Donor. Your mom was busy. You shouldn’t blame her for that. That was a valid decision. At least that sperm wasn’t a drunk. It never blacked your eye cause you talked back.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I just wish she could have gotten the sperm’s name. Only thing I know is he must have had curly hair. She holds open the door for Elle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feminist-themed coffee shop.  33 A woman with a white buzz-cut is hanging up a flyer.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey stranger!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I brought the books.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: What books?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: The books you wanted to buy from me. She puts books on a counter next to soy milk and almond m thermoses.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, umm... Carla glances towards the back of the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Look. Feminine Mystique. First edition, signed. This wine stain? Was left by Betty Friedan herself. Simone de Beauvoir. Germaine Greer! The Female Eunuch! Got some Eileen Myles here, for God’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Un-hunh, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: My granddaughter here googled them, they’re worth thousands and thousands of dollars. Sage gives Elle a look.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (lying) .--Yeah right.  34

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I‘1l let you have em for five- hundred and fifteen dollars, but it’s gottta be right now, cash. Out from the kitchen comes Olivia, Elle’s (now ex) lover, holding a plate with a quesadilla on it for a customer. S has on an apron with a Bonobo ape on it. She freezes upon seeing Elle.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What - what are you doing here? You're not supposed to be working today!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Laurel was sick. She asked me to fill in. Jesus, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I came to sell some stuff. These books. Olivia recognizes the books.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You’re gonna sell these? Why?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I need some cash.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I told you not to cut up your credit card! A woman sitting at a table pipes up.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Is that my quesadilla?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Yes. Sorry. Olivia brings the customer her quesadilla. Elle tries to compose herself.  35

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Okay. (to Carla) Okay, you want to buy these or what? You said you wanted to buy them.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know. I have to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (to customer, distracted) You want - you want hot sauce?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: You have Tabasco?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Tapatio. We have Tapatio. Olivia is glancing over at Elle. Sage is watching their interaction.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Come on, do you want them or not?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I’m thinking. Olivia takes a deep breath and comes back over.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Are you going to introduce me to your granddaughter?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Sure. (turns ) Sage. Olivia.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Olivia. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I’ve seen pictures of you.  36

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Oh. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Bit of a...surprise meeting you like this.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Okay. Wow. Well. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (to Carla) Well?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Look, I’1l give you sixty dollars for them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: All of them?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: So you need money? Because -—

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I do not need money from you. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Okay. ‘Cause -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me? Are you kidding me Olivia? Olivia turns to Carla.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (to Carla) These books are worth more than sixty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I can do my own haggling. Jesus, stop being so nice.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Well stop being so mean! Stop being such a mean asshole! How about that?  37

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Me? Mean? I’m not mean, I’m just not a hypocrite!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: So I’m a hypocrite now?!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (to Olivia) Did you call me earlier? Did you call me and hang up? Twice?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (pause) -..Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t know why.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You just want power. You want to exert your dominance over me! You want to be the Alpha Bonobo!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Guys, take it outside. Elle turns on Carla.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: And you! How come you don’t pay a decent wage, you cheap asshole!

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You heard me! You call yourself a feminist?! It should be illegal, what you pay these kids!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I’m not a kid -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It probably is illegal! You’re not a Bonobo, Carla! You’re a gorilla! You're a Silverback male gorilla! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And she is right! These books are worth way more than sixty dollars!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Grandma, let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: DON’T call me fucking GRANDMA!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (pause) What should I call you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (to Olivia) GO BACK TO SCHOOL. Finish your doctorate. Get your head out of your ass! Stop working at this dump !

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Could I get that hot sauce please?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Sorry - hot sauce?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Here. You want hot sauce? You want hot sauce?!! She grabs some Tapatio and DUMPS IT ALL OVER THE WOMAN’S QUESADILLA.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (laughs) HAH! You’re really off the deep end!

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: That’s it! (picks up books) Take these. I don’t want them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Great and take your sixty bucks and shove em up your ass. Elle leaves.  39

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I’1ll carry them. Olivia follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olivia comes out after Elle and yells.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Why are you acting like these last four months didn’t mean anything?! Why?!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Because they didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I HATE you!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You never did!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Right, cause you never showed me the real you, right?!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s exactly right.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: WELL I’VE GOT NEWS FOR YOU, I SAW

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Your medal’s in the mail.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I’m returning it!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You - you NEOPHYTE! You INGENUE!

dialogues.speaker: SOLIPSIST
dialogues.text: 24 40 Elle walks off.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Uh...nice to meet you... Sage hurries to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You okay to drive?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Fine. (pause) You can call me Grandma. That was just -

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why'd she call you “writer in residence?”

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: ..-She’s calling me a sellout. Cause that’s how I used to make bread. You go someplace, a private college, usually, cause they have the money. You do some readings, you teach some seminars, then you leave, cause you don’t have tenure.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: How is that selling out?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well. It’s not “suffering for your art.” But I had a kid. (pause) I used to drag your mother along with me when she was little. Spent a lot of time in cars, your mother and me.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Well...I’m learning some new insults. My friends pretty much just call each other “bitch” or “ho.” “Slut.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well that’s ignorant bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (pause) So do you think I’m one? A slut?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (looks at her) No. And I don’t want to hear you use that word again. (pause) You know in the 14th century, Chaucer used the word “sluttish” to refer to an untidy man -

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (pause) What’s that noise? There’s a noise from the car.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s the noise the car makes. Let’s go buy a few dollars worth of gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle comes out from a gas station rest room.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: She's pretty. Olivia.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, she’s pretty. That’s what it means, “Olivia.” It means “most beautiful.” So what was she doing with me? Right?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s what you were thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t. It wasn’t actually.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She mailed me an essay she wrote about my poetry. Asked if I’d have coffee with her someday. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because I’m so vain, I said okay. We met for coffee...she was cute. And smart. And she just kept after me. I did more writing in the last four months than in the five year before that. (pause) Anyway, that’s over.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (pause) Grandma, you got any other ideas?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: -..-I’m afraid I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 25 Elle pulls up outside a house with an old motorcycle in f of it. There’s a metal seesaw in the front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle looks at the house.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Wait in the car (pause) On second thought, come with me. The front door of the house opens. KARL steps onto the porch. He’s about 70, muscular, with a pigtail.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Elle? Elle gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Hi there. Hi Karl.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: What a surprise to get your call.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well, it’s been too long. 26  27 43

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Thirty years, Elle. Been thirty years since we last saw each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: God, we’re thirty years older.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: That's how it works. It don’t go backwards. Who’s the young lady?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: This is my granddaughter. Sage.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: “Sage.” Nice name. Pungent.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: You want some zucchini?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s alright. (to Sage) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: How about some corn. I just boiled some corn. Come on. He goes into the house. Elle and Sage follow him. INT. KARL’S KITCHEN - DAY 27 Elle is eating some corn, looking at some framed photos o Sage hangs back.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: (to Sage) Sure you don’t want some corn?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: No thanks. I have...a bit of an upset stomach.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Who are these people?  44

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: My grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You have grandkids now?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I do. You’re not the only one allowed to have grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Which wife is this?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: That? Wife number four. Kid number five. Grandkids number 9, 10 and 11.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're a patriarch.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Iam. I’m biblical. How’s the corn?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Those your own teeth you’re eating with?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Good for you. You were always worried about your teeth. You took good care of them.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: She used to tell me - brush your teeth or you’ll lose them.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Did she, Sage? You know, the teeth are the only thing we see on a person that’1l look the same when they’re dead. When someone smiles at you, they’re showing you their skeleton.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: That’s creepy.  28 29 Elle Sage Karl Elle sock EXT. Sage INT. Karl 45

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Are you married now?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Right now, no. I am currently a man about town. nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Sage, would you let me talk to Karl for a minute? Go look at the flowers out back.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I’1ll go look at the flowers. goes out back.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Are you going to make me a marriage proposal? Now that you know I’m available?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I was just wondering if a wife was going to pop out from somewhere all of a sudden. You want to smoke some weed? laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not? starts to roll a joint from the bag she took from Cam’s drawer.

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You mean business, hunh? KARL’S HOUSE - DAY 28 walks outside the house. It’s strangely tranquil. KARL’S KITCHEN - DAY 29 opens a beer. Elle lights the joint.  46

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Didn't know I'd be having a party today. Care for a beer?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: (drinks) So how’s your partner? Daisy?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Come on. Violet.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: How’s Violet?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She passed away. Two and a half years ago. She’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I am.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Thanks. So listen, you told me if I ever needed anything I should come to you.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Did I? Yes, I guess I did. About five-hundred years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well I need to borrow 500 dollars. Here. Karl takes the joint. Hits on it, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can pay you back in a couple weeks.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: So you’re not just here to smoke a joint with an old flame?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well sure I’m here for that. But I also need 500 bucks.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: You must not have a lot of friends. Current friends.  47

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Guess not. He passes her back the joint.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, you were always good with money, I thought you might be able to help me out.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: What do you need it for?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (exhales ) Rent.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Rent? Why don’t you ask your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: We’re not speaking that often.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. She passes him back the joint.

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) It’s painful seeing you, Elle. Elle opens a beer.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What the hell kind of a thing is that to say?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Just popped into my head. Maybe I’m getting soft. Male menopause, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You’re well past menopause. We both are.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: It’s painful to see you, because it makes me feel old.  48

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I like being old. Young people are stupid.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: We sure were. We sure were stupid.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s an understatement. Can you loan me money?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Sure. I want something in return, though.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: A kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Like a peck?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: No, like a real kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: And then you’1ll loan me the money? Karl nods.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright. Let’s get it over with. She takes the joint from Karl. She takes a hit off it, th she kisses him. It’s not passionate, but it has some affection in it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go. For old times’ sake.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Now I want you to make love with me, just once. For old times’ sake.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself, Karl.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Not really interested in fucking myself, Elle. I wish I was. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I coulda kept out of a lot of trouble over the years. (pause) Okay, well. I gotta go fix this miniature jeep. He goes out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: HEY. WE HAD A DEAL
dialogues.text: Elle follows Karl out. Sage watches her go out. EXT. KARL’S HOUSE - DAY 49 30 Karl opens up a tool box. There is a kid’s-size purple je lying on it’s side by the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Come on, are you out of your mind? He takes out some tools.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I told you. I’m here because I need money. Karl gets down by the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: You wronged me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: This again?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: You were wrong, how you acted.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Forty-nine years ago?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: (nods ) Forty-nine years ago. You were wrong.  50

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well, I was wrong to be sleeping with you, given that I was a lesbian.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: You didn’t seem like a lesbian at the time. When we were living on the boat.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well I was. Just a confused one.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: And that poem you wrote? “The Ogre’s Seed?”

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That wasn’t about you.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: You’re sure you’re not here to say you're sorry? To apologize to me? Finally?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: No. Afraid not. Man, you have eleven grandkids! You can’t let go of old shit?!

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I find that, as I get older, old shit just bubbles up. It bubbles up from the tar. Don’t you find that to be the case? (pause) Look, Elle, I’m not the one who called up from out of nowhere. You're the one rattling the skeletons here. So what are you here for? WHAT ARE YOU HERE FOR?

dialogues.speaker: I'M HERE BECAUSE I NEED SOME GODDAM
dialogues.text: MONEY, BECAUSE I’M THE ONLY IDIOT I

dialogues.speaker: HERSELF.
dialogues.text: (Pause) I knew I was dumb to come here, because I knew you’d be the same selfish bastard you always were. (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Sage comes around the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Wait! Wait - okay. Okay. I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You can?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I can help you. If you need help I can help you. For old times sake. Elle stands there.

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five-hundred?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: ...Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: I have it. Hold on. Karl goes inside. 51 Sage and Elle stand there. Inside the house, Karl goes ov to a bookcase and pulls out a thick old volume (where he hides his cash).

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: He’s not...

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Your grandfather? No. Your grandfather was a fling. One night stand. I have no idea where he is. Karl's a guy I married.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We lived on a sailboat together for two months. Then I split. In the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: This was before Aunt Violet?  52

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Of course it was before Aunt Violet. Karl comes back out. He has some cash in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Hey, so what’s it for? What’s the money for, really?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I told you, it’s for rent.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, you told me that, but you’re a shitty liar.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (pause) It’s true. I am.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: So what’s it for? He turns to Sage.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: It’s...

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She needs to terminate a pregnancy. She’s gonna have an abortion. Beat. Karl pockets the money.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: No. No fuckin’ way.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Karl -

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? Are you out of your God damn mind?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Karl, come on —

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Alright! Alright, Karl! (pause) I’m sorry! Alright? I am sorry. I am not sorry that I did it. But I am sorry that I didn’t tell you. I am sorry I lied to you. That is all I am sorry for. But I am sorry for that.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: It was my decision too!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It’s my body. It’s always been my body!

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: And then you go - you fucking go and have a stranger's baby? You're a psycopath!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Well I wanted a baby. I just didn’t want a God damn husband.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Right, so she grew up with no father.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She grew up fine.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Which is why you don’t speak to her. Elle sags a moment.

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you! He points to Sage.

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does he know? The father?  31 54

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he knows. He doesn’t want it. He doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, at least he knows. At least you had the human decency to tell him. But I’m not paying for it. Karl goes back into his house.

dialogues.speaker: KARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not paying for that. Sage and Elle stand there a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: ...Grandma? (pause) Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on the trunk of Elle’s car. Elle is finishing flossing her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: So you...you had an abortion? Elle’s face fills with stress.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. In someone’s basement.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Was it a doctor? Who did it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: He claimed to have gone to medical school. I don’t believe he ever did.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: -.-Did it hurt? Elle doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So were you... you used to like men?  32 33

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I always liked women. (pause) I just didn’t like myself. (pause) After I had your mom, I knew it was too painful. Life is too painful not to be what you are. Sage looks down.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You don’t know what? (pause) You having second thoughts?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (pause) I want to have a family. I want to have a baby someday. (pause) But not today. Not now. (beat) I want to go to college. I have my GPA up to a B. (beat) Some people...some people could maybe do it all. But I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (pause) You know what we have to do, right?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yes. Sage tears at a fingernail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downtown. Some office buildings. Elle drives, looking for parking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle and Sage are outside a tall office building. different environment than we have been in. 55 32 33  56

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You and me both.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (turns to her) You're scared?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I've been a little scared of your mom since she was five years old. Sage laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, I mean it. The straight A’s. The incessant violin practice. She used to take my cigarettes and empty out the tobacco and replace it with Potpourri that she stole from Vi's closet. I'd light up and get a lungful of potpourri.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Why’d she do that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Cause she wanted me to quit. (pause) And she wanted to torture me. ...Ready? Sage nods. They go into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sage and Elle sit in the waiting room of some corporate offices. They look out of place. A couple of guys in suits are there, glancing at them occasionally. Elle smiles at them and CLUCKS like a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: BAWK-BAWK-BAWK. BAWK-BAWK-BAWK.
dialogues.text: 35 57 The men look away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Sorry. My grandmother’s a chicken. (pause) BAWK. IAN, a sharply dressed young man, comes down the corridor

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: -..-You must be Elle. I’m Ian. Hi Sage.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You guys can follow me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What happened to what’s her name - Tiffany?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know a Tiffany. I replaced Sasha.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Boy, she sure goes through secretaries. You must feel like your head’s on the chopping block. Ian smiles opaquely.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So nice to finally meet you... INT. JUDY’S CORPORATE OFFICE - DAY 35 Judy, Elle’s daughter and Sage’s mother, stands up from behind her desk. She’s attractive and formidable. She is typing an email while walking on a treadmill-desk.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Come in!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Treadmill desk. I’ve had it for two years.  58

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Bit small, isn’t it? (beat) That was a joke.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That's debatable. So what is going on?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Umm...

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Come on. What’s going on? Spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Jesus, why do you have to be so bossy?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Because you are making me anxious, extremely anxious showing up like this, the two of you, in the middle of the day. (to Sage) What’s going on here? Why aren’t you in school?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Because I’m on break.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Right. (pause) Are you pregnant? (pause) Please don’t tell me you’re fucking pregnant. Sage lowers her head. Starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: She’s pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: God damn it. GOD DAMN IT. YOU

dialogues.speaker: CONDOMS IN THERE
dialogues.text: Ian, Judy ‘s secretary, pops his head in the door.  59

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Uh, your four-thirty are here. Should I tell them -

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Umm - I’1l just tell your four- thirty that -

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’ll use the little conference room. (to Elle and Sage) You two wait here. I’11 be back in fifteen minutes. Do not leave. Do not leave. She turns back to Ian.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well? Bring them into the little conference room. And then get me an espresso. Espresso first, actually. Then the clients. Judy and Ian leave. Sage turns to Elle.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (pause) Yeah, we better not.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Elle and Sage sit on the couch. They straighten up as Jud comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This is my fault.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: It's not.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yes it is, because you've been left unsupervised, with way too much free time, for far too long.  60

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I don’t need to be supervised.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Clearly you do. I mean, any idiot would realize you need to be supervised, right? Judy looks at Elle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Are you saying I’m “any idiot?”

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What is your involvement?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: My involvement? I’m her grandmother. And your mother.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yes but what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I’m here for support.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Did you let them use your apartment? For sex?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What? I’m not a pimp.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (to Sage) How far along are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Ten weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Thank God. First trimester. I’m assuming you want to have an abortion.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Who is it? That little creep?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yes.  61

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Uch, really?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We’re not a couple anymore. If we ever really were.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I told you that guy was a loser, didn’t I? I told you he was a flat- out loser.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: You did. You were right.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I was right.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: So you don’t have any God damn money because you spent all your money on shoes and garbage. So it’s my assumption you went to her - (points at Elle) You went to her to get some money but she doesn’t have any money either so you came here. Am I right? Sage hangs her head.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You missed a few steps in between, but you’re right.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: And what about all those condoms I got you?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: We used them.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You and that rodent?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yes.  62

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You can get more, you know. I didn’t make them by hand. I didn’t knit them.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I know. I know. Stop yelling at me.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This isn’t yelling. I'’11 show you yelling. We're going to have to get you an appointment at a clinic.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I already have one. I made an appointment. At 5:45.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That’s in an hour! I can’t take you at 5:45.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I can take her. I can take her. If you pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: We need five hundred dollars more.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Christ. (to Elle) You don’t have five-hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t, at the moment. And I uh...misplaced my credit card. Which I guess makes me some kind of sub-human.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You said it, not me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You know kid, you need a spanking.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I'd like to see you try it. Okay. Let’s go to an ATM.  63

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are at an ATM by the building. Judy puts her card in. Punches in her code.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You weren't going to tell me, were you?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (pause) No, I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I was scared.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Because you're scary. Judy takes out a small stack of money from the machine.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) I'm scary? (nods to Elle) And she’s not?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I didn’t really come here to take crap from you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No, you came here for money.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I haven't asked you for anything in years.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Right. Hooray for you. (beat) There were a lot of things I wanted to pay for. Nurses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn’t my decision. It was hers. You know how private she was.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Really? I just figured it was because you were too proud to ask me for help. Elle doesn’t answer. Judy turns to Sage.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Sage) I am deeply, deeply disappointed in you, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I know.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I thought you were doing better. I thought you were becoming more responsible. Sage is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: -People make mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m aware that people make mistakes. That’s how I make my living, cleaning up after people's mistakes. (to Sage) Here. She holds out the money. Sage takes it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call me when it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: I have to go. Sage walks off.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Would you have told me?  37 38 65

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: That’s up to her. To tell you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You're awful. You’re an awful mother.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I'm an awful mother? (pause) Well, luckily I wasn’t your only mother.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No. Thank God. Thank God for Vi.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe you outta try taking after her more. (beat) Anyway I'll try and be a better grandmother. She turns and follows Sage. Judy looks after her, thinkin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car speeds down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive. Faces tense.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: That went better than I thought it would.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (stewing, angry) That little brat. God damn little brat. Vi spoiled her. She did. She wanted to make all the parenting decisions, Vi did. People thought I was the controlling one. HAH. The car is making a high pitched whine.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna make it on time.  66

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: We'll make it. Elle presses the gas pedal to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll make it if this asshole gets the hell out of the way! She yells at the car in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on asshole! Move over! Get out of the way!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Calm down -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You wanna get there or not?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Be careful -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I am! Sage starts to cry. The CAR NOISE gets louder.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Am I going to hell?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: What if it’s true? What if I’m going to hell?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Along with all the other millions of women and girls who have gotten abortions?

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Along with them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in that vengeful God crap. When you’re dead, you’re dead, end of story. It’s blackness. The void. Might as well face it. (glances over) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Don’t yell at me -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: I’M NOT YELLING!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: YOU'RE JUST LIKE MY MOM! YOU’RE

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: What? You out of your mind?! (yells at car ahead of them)

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT OF THE WAY, MORON
dialogues.text: Elle SWERVES THE CAR ONTO THE RIGHT SHOULDER, BOUNCING AL

dialogues.speaker: WATCH OUT
dialogues.text: The car BOUNCES on the uneven shoulder. There is a LOUD P and the car STOPS ACCELERATING.

dialogues.speaker: DAMN IT
dialogues.text: Elle manages to steer the car safely off to the side of t road until it comes to a stop. Elle is trying to start the car. She can’t.

dialogues.speaker: SHIT
dialogues.text: She opens the door. Pops the hood. A little smoke comes out. She kicks the car.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Piece of shit!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle’s car is in the background, covered by its tarp.  40 68 Elle and Sage hold out their thumbs, trying to hitch a ri

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: «+.SOLrry.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: (looks over) Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: ---I’m sorry. Sage looks at Elle. Then goes back to trying to thumb a ride. A grey minivan pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle and Sage, looking rough, sit in the back section of three-row minivan. There are a suburban dad and mom in the front seats (dad driving). In the middle section are three little kids, strapped int car seats. The kids are zombied out, watching a TV in the ceiling of minivan, which is playing a kids’ movie.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Where are you headed again?

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: A medical clinic. My granddaughter needs to get a procedure Sage starts crying again. The mom looks back.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: It’s gonna be okay, honey. Sage wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: What kind of procedure? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: It’s a female thing.  4l 42 69

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: (squeamish) Oh. Well, don’t worry, we'll get you there!

dialogues.speaker: KID, (AGE 8)
dialogues.text: Quiet! I can’t hear the show!

dialogues.speaker: NO YOU BE QUIET
dialogues.text: The dad clenches his teeth and drives. Elle leans over to Sage.

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Sure you don’t want a kid? Sage looks at Elle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minivan pulls into a small commercial complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van stops and the back hatch opens automatically. Elle and Sage climb out.

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Thank you! The hatchback closes automatically. The clinic entrance is on the second floor, up a flight o stairs. There is a woman by the stairs to the clinic. She has a c table with right to life pamphlets on it. Sitting on a folding chair behind the woman is a six or s year old girl in a pony tail. The van drives off. Sage looks over at the woman nervousl

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, just ignore her.  70 The woman picks up a large wooden sign with a horrific im of a decapitated baby on it.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR
dialogues.text: Don’t kill your baby!

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
dialogues.text: Oh God -

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Just ignore her. The little girl sitting near the woman looks over and the goes back to stringing some colored wooden beads.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR
dialogues.text: Your baby has fingernails!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Not until 22 weeks, genius!

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR
dialogues.text: Baby killing slut!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: Jesus - you talk like that in front of that sweet little girl?

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR
dialogues.text: You go in there, God’s going to send you to hell! You’re going to hell!

dialogues.speaker: ELLE
dialogues.text: You go on ahead, Sage -

dialogues.speaker: SAGE
